awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Risk and reward of high mutation rate: why large populations favor mutators while small populations inhibit them
awd_abstract_narration:
Genetic variation, the raw material for evolution, is ultimately generated by mutation. The rate of mutation is influenced by particular genes, e.g. for DNA replication and repair enzymes, which can themselves be altered by mutations. Some variants of those genes, known as mutators, increase the genomic rate of mutation. Even when mutators have no direct effect on survival and reproduction of the individual, they can experience indirect selection via genetic linkage to beneficial and deleterious mutations that occur elsewhere in the genome.  This proposal explores a novel hypothesis that population size may have an effect on indirect selection experienced by mutators. Understanding the role of population size and spatial structure in shaping the evolution of mutation rate may resolve a longstanding empirical puzzle: why mutators frequently emerge in well-mixed microbial laboratory populations, yet are only sporadically found in nature. This project has important implications for understanding both natural and directed genetic changes in basic, health, conservation, and agriculture research. For example, this research may illuminate the role of mutators during disease progression of cancer tumors. The investigators will also work directly with K-12 teachers and students to improve their understanding of genetics and scientific inquiry. 

Building on several of their previous publications, the applicants present preliminary calculations and experimental results suggesting that large populations enrich for mutators and small populations inhibit them. In specific aim 1, the applicants propose to extend their calculations by developing computer simulations and mathematical analysis to model the evolution of mutators in complex and realistic scenarios, including spatially structured environments. In specific aim 2 the applicants propose to experimentally test their predictions in the laboratory by competing mutator and non-mutator strains of Saccharomyces cerevisiae yeast. Competitions will be monitored by fluorescence and conducted across a range of population sizes and spatial structures.

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

It has been known since the early days of population genetics that population size modulates the efficiency of selection. In small populations, direct selection is overwhelmed by genetic drift, rendering both beneficial and deleterious alleles selectively neutral. Critically, the sign of direct selection never changes with population size ? beneficial mutations never become deleterious and deleterious mutations never become beneficial.

This project examined the role of population size in indirect selection ? selection acting via statistical associations with fitness-affecting mutations elsewhere in the genome. Specifically, we hypothesized that population size can affect not only the efficiency, but also the sign of indirect selection - a phenomenon we have called sign inversion. The major goal of this award was to develop and experimentally test our theory of sign inversion in selection on mutator alleles that increase the genomic mutation rate. These experience indirect selection via statistical association with beneficial and deleterious mutations at other loci.

Outcomes (Intellectual Merit): 

1) We developed an analytical model of mutator fixation to show that mutators have a fixation probability above that of a neutral allele in large populations, but below that in small populations. In other words, mutators switch from being selectively favored to being selectively disfavored as population size decreases. The analytical model revealed that mutators experience sign inversion because indirect selection driven by linkage between mutators and beneficial mutations is overpowered by drift at a larger population size than indirect selection due to the associated deleterious mutational load. The predictions of the analytical model were validated in stochastic computer simulations.

2) To test for the existence of sign inversion empirically, we propagated hundreds of replicate populations of the brewer?s yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae for hundreds of generations at differing population sizes. We showed in three different laboratory environments that mutator yeast were favored over non-mutators in large experimental populations and disfavored in small populations, as predicted. Further analysis of clones isolated from experimental populations confirmed the mechanistic basis of sign inversion predicted by the analytical model.

3) We next explored the evolution of mutators in metapopulations composed of interconnected subpopulations. We showed using computational and experimental metapopulation models that migration can promote mutators in metapopulations composed of small demes that individually disfavor them: with sufficient migration, subdivided metapopulations effectively evolve as large populations that favor mutators. More surprisingly, we found that mutators fare even better in metapopulations with intermediate and rare migration, demonstrating that population subdivision plays a previously unsuspected role in promoting mutator success.

4) Motivated by the analytical results for the fixation probability of a mutator allele, we proved in computer simulations that neither the strength nor the sign of selection on mutators depend on their initial frequency, contrary to the decades-old, established understanding. Instead, we found that the probability of fixation scales with frequency exactly as expected for any frequency-independent beneficial mutation while the per-capita fixation probability at any frequency is equal to that of a single mutator.

5) We have discovered that all known cases of sign inversion involve alleles with ?sign-variable? fitness effects - effects that vary in sign among their carriers with some bearing a cost and some endowed with an advantage. Furthermore, all can be classified depending on whether sign variability manifests between carriers in different lineages of the mutation or among carriers within a lineage. We showed that both between-lineage and within-lineage sign variability can yield sign inversion. Furthermore, by partitioning the fixation probability of each sign-variable allele into component probabilities associated with selection on its cost-bearing and benefit-endowed carriers, we showed that sign inversion always occurs because selection against the former and selection for the latter exhibit differing sensitivities to drift. The common mechanistic basis of sign inversion proves that sign variability is necessary for sign inversion.

 

6) The causal role of sign variability in sign inversion suggests that sign inversion should be common phenomenon given that sign variability is pervasive in nature. We have developed new computational models of the evolution of bet-hedging and ploidy ? two traits with sign-variable effects ? to show that both exhibit sign inversion. We predict that future studies will discover sign inversion in a variety of biological models exhibiting sign variability.

 

Outcomes (Broader Impacts):

1) The award supported the training of 1 post-doctoral associate, 1 graduate student, 2 undergraduate students, and 2 high school teachers from the Providence school district.

2) The award provided support for two collaborations with labs at the University of Pennsylvania and the University of North Carolina.

2) Under the support of this award we have developed a new undergraduate seminar course, designed to help students engage in scientific research. Students in the course learn about the principles, practice, and culture of scientific research, develop practical skills for research participation, and make connections with research labs at the university.
